subject: Re: Unaccounted-for frequencies?
author: mllejade
full_text:
Thanks for the input; I greatly appreciate it.  I'm still on the 
fence, but I'm not ruling anything out.

Sharon the Ignorant Muller

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "LC Duplatt" <lcdupla@...> wrote:
>
> I meant, "It becomes difficult to label responses as "other 
> broadcasts"...
> 
> I was typing too quick.
> 
> LC
> 
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "LC Duplatt" <lcdupla@> wrote:
> >
> > My opinion is that when you work with this, it becomes apparently 
> > clear that the responses become manipulated - meaning, they are 
> > intelligent and in response to questions, etc.  It becomes 
> difficult 
> > to rule out other broadcasts coming through when somebody with a 
> name 
> > like "Rosemary Guiley" hears her name come through a box.  I 
mean, 
> > what are the odds it is coincidence? ;)
> > 
> > LC
> > 
> > --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "mllejade" <leongbabe@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Dear all,
> > > 
> > > From my attempts at making a quick study of EVP-ITC via use of 
> > boxes 
> > > in reading your extremely informative posts and listening to 
> posted 
> > > files, an obvious question arises (please indulge my technical 
> > > ignorance here):  I understand these boxes work on scanning 
radio 
> > > frequencies and that boxes have been created to scan AM, FM, 
and 
> > > shortwave.  What about other frequencies, e.g., walkie-talkie 
> > > channels (public, private and government), television broadcast 
> > > channels, and all the in-between frequencies?  In other words, 
> > while 
> > > scanning, for example, an AM channel, would it not be possible 
> for 
> > > the radio receiver to pick up another band, let's say, short-
> wave?  
> > > The reason I'm asking is that years ago I was dictating 
something 
> > > into the hand-held mic of a cheap cassette tape recorder and 
> > imagine 
> > > my surprise when in playing back what I've just dictated, 
instead 
> > of 
> > > hearing just my voice, I also heard in the background a two-way 
> > > conversation between truckers using their CB radios that my 
cheap 
> > mic 
> > > had picked up while I was recording!
> > > 
> > > My point is even if we're scanning only certain frequencies, 
> can't 
> > > other frequencies bleed through and if so, perhaps this may be 
> the 
> > > reason for some of the non-sequitor responses picked by the 
boxes?
> > > 
> > > Another question:  Astronomers use scanning devices to pick up 
> > > signals from outer space -- are their receivors constructed on 
> > > basically the same principles as the radio receivers in the ITC 
> > > boxes? 
> > > 
> > > Thanks everyone,
> > > 
> > > Sharon the Ignorant
> > >
> >
>
